body:
Right now we are using a couple of different approaches to documenting our JS code:
1. Python style docstrings with `//` comments after the function definition.
2. `/** ... **/` style comments above the function definition that can be read by automated doc generation tools.

I think that 2 produces inline documentation that is very ugly to look at in the code and difficult to write. Others differ, we just need to make a decision.

Technically /**...**/ could work after function def, just the line of function def will be wrong. Would it suit you?

Envoyé de mon iPhone

> Le 26 janv. 2014 à 23:44, "Brian E. Granger" notifications@github.com a écrit :
> 
> Right now we are using a couple of different approaches to documenting our JS code:
> 
> Python style docstrings with // comments after the function definition.
> /*\* ... **/ style comments above the function definition that can be read by automated doc generation tools.
> I think that 2 produces inline documentation that is very ugly to look at in the code and difficult to write. Others differ, we just need to make a decision.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

I find that style of comment marks difficult to work with, no matter where
they appear :(

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

> The end result is a set of **normalized HTML partials** and **a JSON index file** (emphasis mine). Because the index files are loaded separately by the app following the user's preferences, the code also creates a JSON manifest file containing information about the documentations currently available on the system (such as their name, version, update date, etc.).

and also partially there : 
https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/wiki/Adding-documentations-to-DevDocs

Hey there! I'm one of the sprinters from Pycon Montreal, and I would love to crack into this issue. From my personal experience with JS I think we should use JSDoc3 as @Carreau has suggested.

I believe it would also be wise to stick to the commenting conventions that JSDoc3 enforces, because it seems to be the standard across all other JS doc generators, and a convention in the JS community itself. If we were to do otherwise it would probably make it difficult for people who like working on JS stuff to get involved, or we would have to write our own doc generator.

Also, dev docs seems to be a pretty flexible thing, and requires one to write a scraper in order to rip documentation from the original project and collect it into the Dev Doc fold. We would first need HTML documentation in order to write the scraper. I'm still trying to figure out the details on how to write one though.

I'd be happy to make this a pet project of mine! Just let me know!

I am -1 on using JSDoc3

GvR has made fantastic choices over the years to build things into Python
that make developers happy. Triple quoted docstring are one example. They
make it easy to provide inline API documentation for classes and functions
with almost no formatting junk or visual distraction. They are meant to be
read by people who are working with the code.

Things like JSDoc3 come out of the Java world and are designed, in my
humble opinion, to make developers angry and frustrated. Why do I say this?
- The API docs are above the function/class signature, rather than below.
- Complex multiline comment formatting is required. You can't "just write"
- They are designed for machines to parse and render into something pretty.
  They are not designed for developers to read inline.

Our primary usage case for API docs is developers looking at the actual
code, not dev-users reading about our APIs on an HTML web page. I don't
know what the right answer is for generating API docs, but I don't think
that JSDoc3 is it. One very attractive solution is to simply not provide
generated APIs docs for our JavaScript. They are completely unstable so I
am not sure that generating API docs is helpful. I would rather hand write
narrative API docs for the few parts of our APIs that are approaching
stability.

> a convention in the JS community itself. If we were to do otherwise it
> would probably make it difficult for people who like working on JS stuff to
> get involved, or we would have to write our own doc generator.
> 
> Also, dev docs seems to be a pretty flexible thing, and requires one to
> write a scraper in order to rip documentation from the original project and
> collect it into the Dev Doc fold. We would first need HTML documentation in

> I'd be happy to make this a pet project of mine! Just let me know!

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

On Fri, Apr 18, 2014 at 2:53 PM, Freyert notifications@github.com wrote:

> I've been experimenting with JSDoc3 to see if I could alleviate some of
> the concerns you've raised @ellisonbg https://github.com/ellisonbg. I
> think I may have been able to alleviate one of them, but I think I could
> use some more clarification as well.
> - Complex multiline comment formatting is required. You can't "just
>   write".
>   
>   /**Represents a cat.@param {string} color - The cat's fur color.@param {int} age - the cat's age.@constructor*/function Cat(color, age) {
>   this.fur  = color;
>   this.age = age;
>   /** Commands the cat to meow */
>   this.meow = function() {
>      alert("meow");
>   }}
> 
> Does the example avoid the complex formatting you were speaking of? I took
> that to mean comments that look like this . . .
> 
> /**\* Represents a cat.\* @param {string} color - The cat's fur color.\* @param {int} age -  The cat's age.\* @constructor*/
> 
> This solves 1/2 the problem - all the extra starts. There are still two
> other aspect I find problematic:
- The comment/docs are above the function definition. This makes it
  difficult to find the function definition visually.
- The actuall @param {int} stuff is designed for machines, not humans.

> I too hate having to slap all those useless stars into my comments so I
> pleased to find that I didn't have to with JSDoc3, I only have to start my
> comments with /*_. If I have things I *don't_ want JSDoc to parse I could
> use // or /*` with any other amount of stars besides 2.
> 
> Now that I think of it, are do you dislike the whole @param stuff? I feel
> like having a convention like this that contributors can all unanimously
> look to as the standard could be very useful. Let me know what you think!
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/2567#issuecomment-40847842
> .

There seem to be way to include jsdocs in sphinx:
https://jsdoc-toolkit-rst-template.readthedocs.org/en/latest/index.html
I think once we are in typescript we will use typedocs. There are some issues that with current structure where all appears global.

Yeah, one of the main reasons I am so supportive of transitioning to
typescript is that typedoc is so nice.

Hey there, I'm going through old issues and it seems to me that it makes sense to close this one. The [notebook](https://github.com/jupyter/notebook) is no longer  a part of this repository, and from my understanding is no longer  being actively developed, and [JupyterLab docs](https://jupyterlab.github.io/jupyterlab/) adopted conventions inherited from TypeDoc in the TypeScript world. Thanks everyone for participating!

Happy hacking! :bowtie:
